title-group.article-title: Investigation on fracture toughness of aluminum matrix composites reinforced with in situ titanium diboride particles

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Metal Matrix Composites of Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, P. R. China

author-notes.corresp: Haowei Wang, State Key Laboratory of Metal Matrix Composites of Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, P. R. China Email: hwwang@sjtu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Compared to the massive damage caused by SiC/Al2O3 particles to fracture toughness of conventional metal matrix composites in previous reports, an effective improvement in fracture toughness of Al matrix composites with 3, 5.6, and 7.8 vol.% in situ nano/submicron TiB2 has been obtained by improving the particle size and distribution. It is found that the fracture toughness of TiB2/Al composites are only slightly lower than that of the unreinforced alloy, having a mere reduction of 3% to 8%. This is because the in situ TiB2 particles can weaken the damage caused by reinforcing phases to fracture toughness due to their fine sizes, near-spherical shapes, and relatively uniform distributions. Fractography shows the dominant fracture mechanisms of TiB2/Al composites are matrix rupture, eutectic silicon particles fracture as well as TiB2 particles separation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Particulate reinforced metal matrix composites (PRMMCs) have attracted considerable attentions in aerospace and transportation, because of their outstanding combination of mechanical properties such as high specific strength, modulus, and hardness.1–3 However, their fracture toughness are sharply lower, sometimes even less than one half of the matrix alloys due to the incorporation of particles, such as SiC or Al2O3,4–6 and this becomes the main obstacle to their extensive use.

It is reported that the lower fracture toughness of PRMMCs can be mainly attributed to two factors. The first one is related to the constraint on plastic deformation of the matrix by stiff particles.4 Generally, the fracture toughness of PRMMCs decreases as particle volume fraction increases.7 This is because the increase in particle volume fraction leads to the decrease in particle spacing, which causes more severe constraint on matrix deformation. The other factor for the lower fracture toughness is related to the reinforcing particle itself, such as particle clustering, particle fracture, and particle/matrix debonding.8,9 Not only the volume fraction is essential, but also the distribution, size, and shape of particles.5,10,11 Hong et al.8 investigated the effect of clusters on fracture toughness of SiC/2024Al composites, and indicated that the damage accumulation ahead of the crack tended to occur more easily in the region of clustered particles. They noted that the decrease in fracture toughness with increasing cluster was slight up to 20% cluster volume fraction, but beyond this value, the fracture toughness decreased significantly. Song and Huang6 studied three classes of particle size on fracture toughness of SiC/Al composites. A reduction in fracture toughness was obtained with increasing SiC particle size from 10 to 50 µm, which was attributed to the particle fracture and particle/matrix debonding. The fracture toughness of QE22 magnesium alloy with sharp, blocky, and round particles were evaluated by Abachi and Purazrang.12 Since a great amount of stress concentrations was introduced, the composites with sharp particles had the greatest probability of particle fracture, resulting in the lowest fracture toughness. By comparing with previous studies, Schwalbe13 concluded that the homogenously distributed fine and spherical particles can delay the onset of void formation and slow down the void growth, which can enhance the composite’s resistance to fracture. Thus, optimizing the distribution, size and shape of reinforcing particles could weaken the damage by reinforcing phases to fracture toughness of PRMMCs.

The purpose of this work is to explore the possibilities to improve the fracture toughness of PRMMCs by bettering the particles, where in situ TiB2 has been produced with nano/submicron size, near-spherical shape, and relatively homogenous distribution. Actually, pronounced performances on tensile properties14,15 as well as fatigue properties16 were already achieved for the in situ TiB2/Al composites in our previous works, but no work has been given on their fracture toughness and the relevant fracture mechanisms. The effects of TiB2 particles on the fracture toughness and fracture mechanisms of TiB2/Al composites are therefore discussed in this work.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The A356 alloy reinforced with 3, 5.6, and 7.8 vol.% TiB2 particles were fabricated by adding the pre-weighted mixture of K2TiF6 and KBF4 into the molten A356 alloy at 850°C through the exothermic reaction. The melt was stirred using a blade paddle mixer with 600 rpm for 20 min, and then the slag was poured out completely. Finally the melt was poured into the permanent mould to obtain the cast ingot. The heat treatments were then conducted under T6 conditions: solution treatment at 550°C for 12 h, then quenching into the water, and finally aging first at 120°C for 2 h and then at 150°C for 8 h. The A356 alloy was also prepared for comparison. The chemical composition (in wt%) of the matrix and the alloy is Si 7.0, Mg 0.35, Cu 0.1, Fe 0.2, Zn 0.1, Mn 0.1, and balance Al.

sec.title: Particle morphology and tensile property
sec.p:
The morphology and size distribution of TiB2 particles in TiB2/Al composites are shown in Figure 1(a) and (b), respectively. The TiB2 particles are between 30 and 500 nm, with near-spherical shapes and relatively uniform distributions. The room temperature tensile tests were conducted on a Zwick T1-FR020.A50 electronic universal material testing machine at the speed of 1 mm/min. The tensile properties of TiB2/Al composites and unreinforced alloy are presented in Table 1, and the pronounced tensile properties are obtained for the TiB2/Al composites compared with those of the unreinforced alloy. Figure 1.
(a) Morphology and (b) size distribution of TiB2 particles in TiB2/Al composite. Table 1.
Tensile properties of TiB2/Al composites and unreinforced alloy
Material Elastic modulus (GPa) Yield strength (MPa) Ultimate tensiles trength (MPa)
A356 76 236 325
TiB2/Al (3 vol.%) 78 257 344
TiB2/Al (5.6 vol.%) 80 287 347
TiB2/Al (7.8 vol.%) 84 328 382

sec.title: Fracture toughness tests
sec.p: Three-point bending specimens with dimensions of 28 mm × 56 mm × 260 mm were prepared by electro-discharge machining followed by mechanical polishing for the plane-strain fracture toughness test. A 2-mm-width notch was cut for each specimen in accordance with ASTM E399.17 Pre-cracking was performed at the frequency of 5 Hz and the load ratio of 0.1. The tests were then conducted at a crosshead speed of 0.1 mm/min on MTS809 servohydraulic machine. The load and crack opening displacement (COD) was monitored using the 632.C.30 MTS extensometer. Fracture toughness values KQ were calculated from the load–COD curve by Equation (1). Three specimens were tested for each material, and the evaluation of plane-strain requirements can be found in ASTM E399. All tests satisfied the plane-strain requirements and the results were the valid KIC. (1)KQ=PQBW1/2f(a/W) where KQ is the fracture toughness of the specimen, PQ is the force determined by load–COD plot, B is the specimen thickness, W is the specimen width, a is the crack size, and f(a/W) is a geometry-dependent constant from ASTM E399.

sec.title: Fractography observation
sec.p: Fractographies of the TiB2/Al composites and the unreinforced alloy were observed by FEI Sirion 200 scanning electron microscope (SEM) to investigate the effects of TiB2 particles on the fracture toughness and the fracture mechanisms of TiB2/Al composites.

sec.title: Fracture toughness
sec.p:
The plot of fracture toughness (KIC) versus particle volume fraction is presented in Figure 2. The fracture toughness of TiB2/Al composites are only slightly lower than that of the unreinforced alloy, having a mere reduction of 3% to 8%. Moreover, the fracture toughness of TiB2/Al composites decreases progressively with increasing TiB2 volume fraction, attributing to the constraint on matrix deformation by the hard TiB2 particles. However, compared with that of the unreinforced alloy, the reduction in fracture toughness of 5.6 vol.% TiB2/Al composite in this work presents 5%, while the reduction in that of 5.6 vol.% Al2O3/Al composite in the study4 was 34%. Furthermore, the reduction in fracture toughness of 7.8 vol.% TiB2/Al composite in the present work is only 8%, while the reduction in those of 10 vol.% SiC/Al composites in Song and Huang6 were 26–36%. These indicate that, compared with the conventional SiC or Al2O3 particles in previous reports, the in situ TiB2 particles in the present work can, to some extent, weaken the damage by particles to fracture toughness, though the real difference should be studied in order to make quantitative comparisons with Song and Huang.6 Figure 2.
Fracture toughness vs particle volume fraction.

sec.title: Fractography
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the overall fractographies of the unreinforced alloy and the TiB2/Al composites. Compared with the unreinforced alloy (Figure 3(a)), the TiB2/Al composite reveals a cleavage-and-dimple morphology due to the incorporation of TiB2 particles, as shown in Figure 3(b)–(d). Small dimples can be seen on the fracture surface. The dimples are the consequence of the presence of hard TiB2 particles in the ductile aluminum matrix. Generally, brittle fracture of a particle or debonding at the particle/matrix interface leads to the formation of voids and consequently of dimples. On the other hand, void and dimple formation mechanisms are due to slip plane/slip plane or slip plane/grain or phase boundary interactions.13 With increasing TiB2 volume fraction from 3 to 7.8 vol.%, the probability of void and dimple formation increases (Figure 3(b)–(d)). The increase in volume fraction leads to the decrease in particle spacing, which not only causes more severe constraint on matrix deformation, but also can make the already formed voids easier to grow and coalesce, resulting in the decreased fracture toughness. It can also be seen from Figure 3(b)–(d) that large crack (even longer than 10 µm) appears within the matrix, indicating that the dominant fracture mechanism of TiB2/Al composites is matrix rupture. On the other hand, cracks may also initiate at the eutectic silicon particles, shown in Figure 4(a), which is detrimental to the fracture toughness. However, the presence of TiB2 particles can refine the eutectic silicon particles within the matrix during the fabrication process, and may weaken the damage by eutectic silicon particles to the fracture toughness of TiB2/Al composites compared with that of the unreinforced alloy. Furthermore, it is observed from Figure 4(b) that there is no any cracking in the TiB2 particles. One can reasonably expect that, once the crack encounters with the in situ TiB2 particles, it prefers to detour them as those endogenous TiB2 particles are fine and flawless,15,18 and therefore the crack-free morphology of TiB2 particles can be seen. Conversely, the fractured SiC or Al2O3 particles in conventional composites have been observed due to the greater probability of finding a critically sized flaw within them,19 e.g., the fractured Al2O3 particles had always be seen on the fracture surfaces of 1–50 µm-Al2O3 reinforced 6061Al composite in Park et al.,4 which became the predominant crack initiation mechanism of the composite. Song and Huang6 investigated the fracture toughness of Al alloys reinforced with various sizes of SiC particles. The increased probability of particle fracture was reported as the increase in SiC particle size. This is also in good agreement with the normal conclusions that the plastic strain needed to cause fracture a particle increases with decreasing particle size.13 Schwalbe13 demonstrated that particle size reduction without changing the volume fraction caused an increase of KIC in spite of the reduced particle spacing. The better resistance of smaller particles overrode the detrimental effect of reducing the particle spacing. Figure 3.
Overall fractographies of (a) unreinforced alloy; (b) 3 vol.% TiB2/Al composite; (c) 5.6 vol.% TiB2/Al composite; and (d) 7.8 vol.% TiB2/Al composite. Figure 4.
Fractographies of TiB2/Al composites: (a) cracked eutectic silicon and (b) crack-free TiB2 particles.

Furthermore, observing the features of the in situ TiB2 particles (Figures 1(a) and 4(b)), it is found that most of them are intrinsically near spherical in shape. Although the spherical shapes are not surprising within most of the in situ particle fabrications, this factor is greatly in favor of the improvement in fracture toughness of TiB2/Al composites. As is well known, sharp particles can readily introduce severe stress concentrations, even making the particles fracture at a lower strain.12 On the contrary, the in situ fine near-spherical TiB2 particles not only markedly release the particle stress concentrations, but also relieve the matrix strain concentrations near the particles, and therefore weaken their damage to fracture toughness. In addition, the homogeneity of TiB2 particles also contributes to the improved fracture toughness. It is indicated that the clustering of particles had two important effects on the fracture toughness of the composites. First, they decreased the length of the ligament locally. Second, they increased the size of microcracks.6 Both effects degraded the fracture toughness. Nevertheless, the uniformly dispersed TiB2 particles could avoid the formation of microcrack and make the matrix have much more ability to deform, leading to the improvement in fracture toughness.

However, as observed from Figure 4(b), there are some dimples that are of similar size to TiB2 particles but have no particles inside, indicating that the TiB2 particles have separated from the dimples. It can be concluded that besides matrix rupture and eutectic silicon fracture, another fracture mechanisms of TiB2/Al composites can be found: TiB2 particle/matrix interface debonding. As is known, there is residual tension stress within the matrix and residual compressive stress within the particles due to the different thermal expansion coefficient between particles and matrix.14 Thus, the particle/matrix interfaces may suffer the tension stress, which leads to the interface failure as the cyclic load involved. The TiB2 particle/matrix interface failure is one of the reasons for the decreased fracture toughness with increasing TiB2 volume fractions.

list-item.p: The fracture toughness of TiB2/Al composites were only slightly lower than that of the unreinforced alloy, having a mere reduction of 3% to 8%. With increasing TiB2 volume fraction from 3% to 7.8%, the fracture toughness of TiB2/Al composites decreased progressively.
In situ TiB2 particles could weaken the damage by reinforcing phases to fracture toughness due to their fine sizes, near-spherical shapes and relatively uniform distributions.

The dominant fracture mechanisms of TiB2/Al composites were the matrix rupture, eutectic silicon particles fracture as well as the TiB2 particle/matrix debonding. There was no cracking in the TiB2 particles on the fractography of TiB2/Al composites.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.p: The authors are indebted to Xiangqi Meng and Zhuoying Lin for their experimental assistance.
